Award.AwardTitle: Mesoscale Plasticity: Dislocation Patterns, Stochastic and Size Effects

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advancing and accelerating materials discovery depends on our ability to develop models that can allow rapid investigation of large materials spaces to optimize properties, and to design manufacturing processes that yield the desired mechanical behavior on the basis of verifiable simulations. Of particular interest are the material properties of systems which consist of multiscale structural components whose dimensions lie in the range of a few nanometers to a few hundred micrometers. This includes micro-electro-mechanical systems, micro implants and microelectronic devices. At small length scales the measured mechanical properties vary significantly with decreasing dimensions. While existing models can predict deterministic values, analytical models often implicitly assume that noise in the data is due to difficulties inherent in microscale testing techniques. However, experiments show a significant amount of stochastic behavior no matter how elegantly the experiments are performed. This award supports fundamental research to develop predictive models that account for stochastic phenomena to ensure that validation techniques and simulation tools are well paired. Further broader impact will be the creation of a diverse environment in our laboratories in terms of race, gender, and national origin. This project offers students and junior researchers opportunities to participate in a research and education experience in an interdisciplinary environment, tackling their thesis problems with co-advisement from faculty drawn from both mechanics and materials science.

The research activities will develop mechanics and materials science theories and testing schemes as metrics for material modeling and experimental validation. Our hypothesis is that plastic deformation in small volume is stochastic, serrated and heterogeneous. Such effects would arise from the stochastic nature of the underlying microstructure such as dislocations, grain size, interfaces and grain boundaries, from stress gradients arising from loading conditions and morphological defects, and the formation of localized and dislocation patterns. We will develop models that account for such phenomena so that validation techniques and simulation tools are well paired. Towards this end, this project will address the following five questions. 1) What are the underlying causes of the observed stochastic phenomena: onset of plasticity, localization, patterning, and serrated flow? 2) How do deformation mechanisms and defect-surface interactions contribute to strength, toughness, and damage in small volumes? 3) Under what morphological and microstructural conditions does the deformation behavior transition from deterministic to stochastic? 4) How can we quantify and model stochastic behavior across length scale? 5) How can we translate this understanding into a mesoscale stochastic size-dependent plasticity model?

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
A long-running goal in mechanics and materials engineering is to be able to develop theories and predictive models that can make it possible to optimize properties and to design manufacturing processes that yield materials possessing desired mechanical behavior on the basis of verifiable simulations.  Of particular interest are the material properties of systems, which consist of structural components whose dimensions lie in the range of a few tens of nanometers to a few hundred micrometers.  This includes, for example, micro-electro-mechanical systems, micro implants and microelectronic devices.  However, at small length scales, while traditional models predict deterministic and size-independent behavior, experiments show a significant amount of stochastic and size-dependent behavior with decreasing dimensions.

This project set out to develop testing schemes, theories and models that account for length scale, size effects and stochastic deformation phenomena. The length scales of interest were on the dislocation scale (a dislocation is a defect responsible for permanent deformation in metals), on the single crystal grain scale, and on the polycrystalline scale (a metal consists of many crystalline grains that are randomly oriented with respect to each other).

The theories, models, and simulations involved discrete dislocations (microscale), information from this was passed to describe the behavior and patterning of many dislocations in a single crystal  (mesoscale), and then the performance of a crystal with many dislocations was passed to plasticity models to predict the behavior of many grains in a polycrystal (continuum polycrystalline scale).  In parallel, mechanical and microstructural characterization experiments using nano-indentation, tensile testing, electron backscatter diffraction, and orientation imaging microscopy, were carried out on a number of metals with varying microstructures, including grain boundary characteristics, grain size and their spatial distributions that were obtained through different material processing methods.  

The main results generated by this work have been published in a series of articles and presented at national and international engineering conferences. The key element in these articles focused on describing deformation in metals at various length scales in statistically applicable ways.  It was shown that the stochastic behavior could be attributed to a number of microstructural features, such as dislocation content, crystalline phases, crystal orientations, grain boundaries, and grain size, and their spatial distributions.  Furthermore, it was shown that a dislocation-based plasticity model, incorporating these features, could predict the deformation behavior and the evolution of the underlying defect microstructures.  Thus, it is suggested that measuring, modeling, predicting and verifying distributions of properties and mechanical behavior improve the ability to optimize material properties in future designs.

The project provided training to graduate as well as undergraduate students in a diverse research laboratory environment. The students were mentored in developing methods to explain science and engineering results to broad groups of scientists as well as younger students. The undergraduate student participants worked closely with the graduate student participants. This provided mentoring opportunities to the graduate students who gained a significant amount of experience in learning how to present complex topics to younger students in an engaging manner.  The students also had opportunities to participate in local and national technical meetings, and to interact with student participants from NSF supporting Research Experience for Undergraduate sites at Washington State University. 

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2018
Modified by: Hussein M Zbib
